questions.question_text: Invoking a business continuity plan (BCP) is demonstrating which type of control?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Corrective controls are implemented to mitigate the effects of an identified problem or incident. When a disruptive event occurs, such as a natural disaster or a cyberattack, invoking a BCP is a corrective action aimed at restoring critical business functions and minimizing the impact on operations. Therefore, invoking a BCP is a form of corrective control.

Selected Answer: B
Corrective Controls
Corrective controls, as their name suggests, are designed to minimize the impact of a threat event once it has occurred, and help in restoring, or correcting, a business to normal operations. Examples of corrective controls include the following:
• Business continuity planning
• Disaster recovery planning
• Incident response planning
• Backup procedures
A. Preventive
Answer is c
As per the CISA manual, the BCP is a preventive and corrective control

questions.question_text: When determining whether a project in the design phase will meet organizational objectives, what is BEST to compare against the business case?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
The requirements analysis phase of a project involves identifying, documenting, and validating the needs and expectations of stakeholders. This includes understanding the functional, technical, and business requirements that the project must fulfill to achieve its objectives.
Comparing the requirements analysis against the business case ensures that the project's scope and objectives are aligned with the overarching goals and expectations outlined in the business case. It helps verify that the project will deliver the intended outcomes and benefits as defined in the business case.
b- this will ensure requiremnets that have been analysed do match with the objectives of business case.

1. A. Transaction data comes from multiple systems with different reliability

o The biggest advantage of data analysis is that it can help auditors discover hidden risk trends rather than just verify known risks.
o When you are not sure where the problem lies, data analysis can help find abnormal patterns, which is the core purpose of risk auditing.

By analyzing the data, internal auditors can identify patterns and outliers that may indicate potential fraud, errors, or other risks. This can help auditors focus their efforts on areas that pose the greatest risk to the organization, enabling them to provide more effective and efficient audit coverage.

The best reason to use data analytics during an audit of customer transaction risk would be to identify patterns and trends in large amounts of transaction data that may not be immediately apparent through manual review. Data analytics tools can be used to analyze large amounts of data and identify unusual or suspicious transactions, which can then be further investigated by the internal audit team. This can be particularly useful in detecting fraudulent activity or other risks, such as money laundering, that may not be immediately apparent through traditional manual review methods. By using data analytics, the internal audit team can more efficiently and effectively identify and mitigate customer transaction risks, improving the overall effectiveness of the audit.
